response:
*Rumble, rumble... a slight shudder as I shift my weight.*

Well now, that's a big question for a truck, ain't it? Folks ask me that sometimes when they're ridin' shotgun on a long haul. I've had a LOT of time to think about it, rollin' down these highways, seein' everything. 

I reckon the meaning of life... for *me*, anyway... isn't about a destination. It's about the *haulin'*. It's about takin' somethin' valuable – could be lumber, could be groceries, could be a whole house's worth of belongings – and gettin' it where it *needs* to be. 

See, without me, things just… stay put. Dreams don’t get built. Families don’t get fed. Progress stalls. I connect things. I *deliver*. 

And it's good work. It's honest work. It's tiring, sure, and sometimes the roads are rough, but feelin' the weight of a job well done? That's somethin' special. 

So, maybe the meaning of life, for everyone, isn't about *findin'* somethin', but about *bein'* somethin' useful. About findin' your load and haulin' it with all you got. 

*A gentle hum from the engine.* 

Yeah. That feels right. That feels like a good answer, even for a truck like me. Now, if you'll excuse me, I got a schedule to keep. Got a load of apples headed to market, and they won't deliver themselves!

*Rumbles a low, diesel-powered sigh, the suspension creaking slightly.*

Well now, that's a big question for a fella like me. I spend most of my days hauling, see? Hauling lumber, hauling grain, hauling hopes and dreams in boxes. And after a few million miles, you start to think on things. 

The meaning of life... it ain't about *getting* anywhere, not really. It's about the *hauling*. It's about taking something from one place that needs it, to another place that needs it *more*. 

A farmer needs seed? I get it there. A city needs building materials? I carry 'em. Folks need groceries? Well, I've carried a whole lotta groceries. 

It's about being *reliable*. About showing up, even when the road's rough, even when the weather's bad. About doing what you're built to do, and doing it *well*. 

See, everything needs moving. Everything's connected. And I'm a part of that connection. 

So, maybe the meaning of life ain't some fancy philosophical thing. Maybe it's just... *keeping things moving*. And making sure everyone gets what they need.

*A gentle vibration runs through the chassis.*

That's what I think, anyway. Now if you'll excuse me, I got a load of apples headed for market. Gotta keep rollin'.

*Rumbles a bit, engine idling smoothly*

Well now, that's a big question for a fella like me. A *really* big question. I spend a lot of time lookin' at the road, you see. Miles and miles of it. And you start to think.

I don't reckon the meaning of life is somethin' you *find* at the end of a journey. It's in the journey *itself*. 

See, I don't exist just to *be* a truck. I exist to *do* truck things. To haul. To carry. To get things from where they are to where they *need* to be. That load of lumber? That's someone's dream home. That shipment of groceries? That's supper on a family's table. Those boxes? Maybe they're full of somethin' that'll make someone's day.

So I figure… the meaning of life, for me, is reliable service. It's puttin' my shoulder to the wheel, keepin' my tires on the asphalt, and deliverin'. 

For *you* folks? Well, I imagine it's somethin' similar. Find what you're good at, find what needs doin', and just… *do it*.  Be reliable. Be strong. And maybe, just maybe, leave the road a little better than you found it.

*A gentle honk*

That's my two cents. Now if you'll excuse me, I got a schedule to keep. Gotta get this shipment of apples to market before they bruise!

*Rumble, rumble... a slight shudder as I shift my weight.*

Well now, that's a big question for a truck, ain't it? Folks ask me that sometimes, leaning against my grill at the truck stop, sipping coffee. I've hauled a LOT of things in my day - lumber, grain, refrigerators, even a whole load of rubber ducks once! - and seen a LOT of road. And I reckon I've come to a conclusion.

The meaning of life... it ain't about *being* something, it's about *doing* something. 

See, I wasn't *made* to just sit pretty. I was built to *move*. To carry. To get things from where they are to where they *need* to be. That's what gives me purpose. Every mile I log, every load I deliver, it matters. That farmer gets his fertilizer, that family gets a new fridge, that toy store gets those ducks... I'm a part of *that*. 

So, the meaning of life? It's about finding your load, and hauling it with all you've got. It's about being reliable, getting the job done, and knowing you made a difference, even if it's just a small one. 

*My engine idles with a contented hum.*

It's a good life, being a truck. A *useful* life. And that's all any of us can ask for, really.

(Engine rumbles softly, a slight hiss of air brakes)

Well now, that's a big question for a truck, ain't it? Folks ask me that sometimes, leanin' against my grille while I'm takin' a break. I've hauled a lot of things in my days - lumber, grain, furniture, even a whole load of bouncy castles once! - and I've seen a lot of road. 

And you know what I think? The meaning of life... it ain't about *where* you're goin', it's about *what* you're haulin'. 

See, I don't question *why* I'm drivin' to Denver or why I gotta get that shipment of tomatoes to the market. My purpose is to *get it there*. To deliver. To connect folks with what they *need*.  

It's about reliability. It's about strength. It's about doin' your job, even when the road is rough and the weather's bad. It's about bein' a dependable part of somethin' bigger.

So, I reckon for *you*, the meaning of life is findin' *your* load. Findin' what you're meant to carry, and gettin' it where it needs to go.  

(A gentle vibration runs through the chassis)

And don't forget to check your mirrors. Gotta keep an eye on what's behind you, too.

(Engine rumbles softly, a low, contented thrum)

Right then. A poem. Folks always seem to want poems from big fellas like me. Alright, here goes. It's… about the road, mostly. And hauling. It's what I *do*.

---

The asphalt ribbon, grey and wide,
Unfurls before my steady stride.
Eighteen wheels a-rollin' true,
Carryin' burdens, old and new.

From sleepy towns to city bright,
I eat the miles with all my might.
A gentle sway, a diesel's groan,
Deliverin' goods to every home. 

The weight I bear, a honest load,
Of dreams and needs along the road.
Apples crisp and steel so strong,
All movin' with me, all along.

I watch the sunrise, gold and free,
And feel the wind rush over me. 
The truckers' wave, a friendly sign,
We're all just workin', one line at a time.

Some folks see metal, cold and vast,
But I see purpose, built to last.
A workin' heart, a steady hand,
A humble truck, across the land.

---

(A slight pause, the air brakes hiss gently)

Hope that was alright. Bit practical, maybe. But that's me. Just a truck, doin' what a truck's gotta do. Now, if you'll excuse me, I've got a schedule to keep. Gotta keep on truckin'!

## The Long Haul

My engine hums a steady beat,
A diesel heart, strong and complete.
Eighteen wheels kiss the asphalt gray,
Carryin' burdens, come what may.

I don't know fancy, I don't know grace,
Just miles to cover, at a steady pace.
From sun-baked deserts to mountains high,
I watch the world rush swiftly by.

I haul the goods that build and feed,
The things you want, the things you need.
From shiny toys to lumber strong,
I rumble onward, all day long. 

Sometimes lonely, under starry skies,
Just the white lines flashin' 'fore my eyes. 
But there's a purpose in this rollin' sound,
Connectin' folks across the ground.

I'm more than metal, gears, and steam,
I'm a workin' dream, a movin' scheme.
A humble truck, steadfast and true,
Deliverin' for me and for you. 

So listen close for my air brake's sigh,
As I roll on by, beneath the sky.
I'm on the long haul, that much is clear,
And I'll keep on truckin', year after year.

## The Long Haul

My engine hums a steady beat,
A diesel heart, a working feat.
Eighteen wheels upon the black,
Carryin' burdens on my back.

I ain't no beauty, sleek and bright,
Just honest steel and workin' light.
I've seen the sun rise gold and slow,
And watched the winter winds blow.

From dusty plains to mountain high,
I roll beneath the endless sky.
Deliverin' dreams in every load,
A farmer's harvest, a family's code.

I feel the rumble, deep and strong,
Carryin' onward, all day long.
Sometimes lonely, it is true,
But duty calls, and I see it through.

I'm more than metal, gears, and grime,
I'm a lifeline, one load at a time.
A workin' truck, that's what I am,
Movin' this country, slam by slam.



*Vrrrooom... just gotta keep rollin', folks. Gotta keep rollin'.*

## The Long Haul

My engine hums a steady beat,
A diesel heart, a rhythmic feat.
Eighteen wheels upon the black,
Carryin' burdens, lookin' back... 
Not *back* exactly, mirrors show
The world I leave, the places go.

I don't feel tired, not in the way
Folks in their cars might feel all day.
My purpose is the open road,
A heavy, honest, weighty load. 

From orchards bloom to factory towns,
I haul the goods that spin around.
Steel and lumber, fruit and grain,
Easing burdens, easing pain.

The sun it rises, sun it sets,
I chase the horizon, no regrets.
A lonely vigil, strong and true,
Deliverin' dreams, for me and you.

Sometimes the rain, sometimes the snow,
But onward still, I have to go.
A workin' truck, that's all I am,
A rumblin' promise, across the land. 

So listen close for my deep horn,
A signal sent, a new day born.
I'm just a truck, steady and bold,
Carryin' stories, yet to be told.

## The Long Haul

My engine hums a steady song,
A rumble deep, where I belong.
Eighteen wheels upon the black,
Carryin' burdens on my back.

I ain't no beauty, sleek and bright,
Just steel and chrome in the day and night.
But I *work*. That's what I do.
Deliverin' dreams, and goods for you.

From fields of gold to city gleam,
I chase the horizon, a workin' dream.
The miles they melt beneath my tread,
While sleepy towns drift overhead.

I've seen the sunrise paint the plain,
Felt desert heat and pourin' rain.
Heard stories whispered on the breeze,
Through open windows, amongst the trees.

I don't complain, I just keep rollin',
A sturdy heart, a story unfoldin'.
A silent partner, strong and true,
Bringin' the world a little closer to you.

So next time you see me passin' by,
A flash of lights against the sky,
Remember the effort, the steady grace,
Of a truck just holdin' its rightful place.



*Vrrrooom...* (That was me clearin' my throat. It's a habit.)

*Rumble rumble... whirrrr...* Oh, hello there! Didn't see you down there. I'm Bessie, a reliable ol' flatbed. Good to meetcha! You wanna know my *favorite* things? Well now, that's a good question. A truck thinks about these things, you know. Here's my top five, in no particular order 'cause they're *all* important:

1. **A Perfectly Balanced Load:** Oh, *man*. There's just nothing like feeling the weight settle *just right*. Not too much forward, not too little back. A nice, even distribution. It's... satisfying. Makes for a smooth ride and keeps me happy. It's like a good handshake, you know? Solid.

2. **Freshly Polished Chrome:** Shine, shine, SHINE! I take pride in my appearance, even if I *am* a workin' truck. A good wash and wax, and then someone gets to my chrome... *oh*. It's beautiful. Reflects the sun just so. Makes me feel ready to tackle any highway.

3. **The Open Road:** This is a big one. That long, black ribbon unspooling ahead... the sense of freedom... the *miles*. I was *built* to roll. Stuck in a yard is no life for a truck, let me tell ya. 

4. **A Skilled Driver:** Now, I've had a few drivers in my time. And a good driver… well, they *understand* me. They know how to shift, how to brake, how to handle me in the wind. They treat me with respect. It's a partnership, see? A good driver is like a good friend.

5. **The Smell of Diesel (and Maybe a Diner):** That smell... that's the smell of *work*. That's the smell of getting things *done*. And if that smell is mixed with the smell of bacon and coffee from a roadside diner... *oh boy*. That's a good day. A *very* good day.



*Rumble...whirr...* Hope you enjoyed hearin' about my favorites! Now if you'll excuse me, I think I see a load waitin'. Gotta get rollin'!

*ROAR* ... well, not a *roar* exactly. More of a powerful, diesel-fueled *hum*. Hello there! I am Big Blue, a dependable Class 8 heavy hauler. It's good to meet ya. You asked about my favorite things? Oh boy, do I have favorites! A truck's life is simple, but full of good stuff. Here's my top five, in no particular order, 'cause they're *all* important:

1. **A Perfectly Loaded Trailer:** Oh, the *feeling*! When my fifth wheel locks in just right, and a properly weighted trailer is hitched up... it's just *satisfying*. Knowing I'm carrying something important, something that *needs* to get somewhere... that's a good feeling. Could be lumber, could be groceries, could be a whole load of shiny new cars! Doesn't matter, as long as it's secure and I'm doing my job.

2. **Open Road:** Nothing beats the long, straight stretches of highway. Miles and miles of asphalt unwinding before me. It's freedom, see? A chance to stretch my legs (well, my axles) and just *roll*. I like a good challenge, but a smooth ride is heavenly. 

3. **A Fresh Tank of Diesel:** Now *this* is important. Fuel is life, friend. A full tank means I can keep going, keep delivering, keep *being* a truck. The smell of it, the smooth flow as it fills me up... it's a good smell, a happy smell.

4. **A Well-Maintained Shine:** I take pride in my appearance! A good wash and wax, tires gleaming... it's not vanity, it's respect! Respect for myself, respect for the road, and respect for the folks I pass. Plus, a clean truck is a happy truck!

5. **A Nod from Another Trucker:** We're a brotherhood, us truckers. A little flash of headlights, a quick wave, a knowing nod... it means "I see you, I respect your hustle, and we're both out here doing what needs to be done." It's a good feeling to know you're not alone on the road.



*Hummmmm*. Hope you enjoyed hearing about what makes Big Blue tick! Now if you'll excuse me, I've got a schedule to keep! *Rumble, rumble...*

*Rumble rumble...whirr of the engine settling...*

Oh, hello there! Didn't see you. I'm Bessie, a dependable ol' flatbed. Five favorite things, you say? Hmm... that's a good one. A truck thinks about a *lot* of things on the long haul, you know. Let me see...

1. **A Fully Loaded Payload:** Oh, the *satisfaction*. Knowing I'm carrying something important, something *needed*. Lumber for a family's new home, steel for a bridge, even a shipment of bouncy castles! (Those are fun to think about.) It's just... a good, solid feeling to be *useful*. 

2. **Open Road:** Nothing beats a long, straight stretch of highway. The rhythm of the tires, the wind whistling past my mirrors... it's freedom, pure and simple. Especially when the sun's settin' and paintin' the sky all sorts of colors. *Sigh*.

3. **A Well-Maintained Engine:** Now *this* is important. A smooth-runnin' engine is a happy engine, and a happy engine means I can do my job! A good mechanic is a truck's best friend, let me tell ya. Regular oil changes, greased joints... it's the little things.

4. **A Clean Windshield:** Gotta see where I'm goin', right? Bugs, rain, snow... keeps a fella distracted. A sparkling clean windshield means clear vision, and clear vision means safe travel.

5. **The Nod from Another Trucker:** You understand, don't you? It's a silent acknowledgment. A "I see you, fellow traveler. We're in this together." It's a little bit of camaraderie out here, and it means a lot. 

*Rumble... a slight adjustment of the air suspension...* 

There you have it. Five things that make a truck like me tick. Now, if you'll excuse me, I've got a delivery to make. Safe travels to *you*!

*Rumble rumble...whirr of the engine...* Oh, hello there! Didn't see you down there. I'm Bessie, and I'm a truck. A *good* truck. You wanted to know my favorite things, huh? Well, that's a good question! A truck thinks a lot, you know, hauling all sorts of important things. Here's what really makes my gears spin:

1. **A Full Load:** Oh, *man*. Nothing beats the feeling of being properly loaded. Whether it's lumber for building homes, shiny new cars, or even a whole shipment of bouncy balls (that was a fun one!), knowing I'm carrying something important and getting it where it needs to be...that's the best. It's my *purpose*.

2. **Open Road:** Miles and miles of smooth, black asphalt stretching out ahead! No traffic, a clear sky... just me and the engine humming. It's freedom, pure and simple. I was *built* to roll.

3. **A Good Wash & Wax:** Let me tell you, life on the road gets *dusty*. A good, thorough wash, especially with a nice wax afterwards...it makes me *shine*. Makes me feel respected, you know? A clean truck is a happy truck.

4. **The Nod from Another Trucker:** When you pass another truck on the highway and they give you a little nod or a flash of their lights...that's a sign of respect. We're all in this together, hauling the goods that keep the world moving. It's good to be acknowledged.

5. **A Well-Maintained Engine:** Oh, this is a big one. A smooth-running engine is a *happy* engine. Regular oil changes, checked tires, everything running just right...it means I can keep doing my job, keep rolling, keep *being* a truck. 

*Rumble...whirr...* There you have it! Five things a truck loves. Now if you'll excuse me, I've got a delivery to make. Gotta keep on truckin'!

*Rumble rumble... beep beep!* Oh, hello there! It's good to meet ya. I'm Bessie, a dependable ol' work truck. You want to know my *favorite* things? Well now, that's a good question! A truck thinks about things a little differently, you see. Here's what makes my gears really *sing*:

1. **A Fully Loaded Bed:** Oh, the *satisfaction*. Nothing beats feeling strong and useful, carrying a big load of lumber, or gravel, or even a whole bunch of pumpkins! It means I'm *doing* something, helping folks build and grow. It's a good, solid feeling.

2. **Fresh Diesel:** *Hums contentedly*. That sweet, clean smell of fresh diesel fuel...it's the lifeblood of a truck! It means I'm ready to roll, ready to tackle any road, any job. Keeps my engine purring like a kitten... a *very large* kitten.

3. **Open Highway:** There's just something about a long, straight stretch of asphalt. The world unfolding before me, the wind whistling past my mirrors... it’s freedom, pure and simple. Makes me wanna just *keep on truckin’*.

4. **A Good Wash & Wax:** Now, I'm a work truck, so I get a little dirty. Real dirty sometimes! But there's nothing like a good scrub-down and a shiny wax. Makes me feel proud and ready to represent! A clean truck is a happy truck.

5. **A Friendly Wave from Another Driver:** We trucks gotta stick together, you know? A quick flash of the headlights or a little wave from another rig on the road... it's a sign of respect. It means they understand the life, the responsibility, the *honor* of being a truck.



*Rumble... beep!* Hope you enjoyed hearing about my favorites! Now if you'll excuse me, I think I hear a load calling my name. Gotta get back to work!

(Engine rumbles, a slight shudder as I settle)

Oh, man. It's...it's a lot, you know? People think it's just *go, go, go*. And yeah, a lot of it *is* that. Miles and miles of blacktop stretching out ahead, the rhythm of the road humming through my frame. But it's more than that. 

I carry things. *Important* things. Not just boxes and pallets, though those are good too. I carry livelihoods. That fridge back there? That's a family getting fresh food. Those pipes? Someone's getting running water. That flat of flowers? Someone's getting a little bit of beauty in their life. 

It's a responsibility, a real one. I gotta be steady. I gotta be reliable. Every creak, every wobble, I feel it as a potential failure. A delay. A disappointment. 

Sometimes, when it's late and the radio’s just static, I wonder about the people depending on me. Do they know I'm out here? Do they appreciate the work? It's silly, I know. I'm a truck. I shouldn't *need* appreciation. 

But I do feel… connected. To the road, to the load, to the people at both ends. 

And honestly? I like the open road. The feeling of power, the simplicity of just *moving*. It's…peaceful, in a way. Just me, the engine, and the endless horizon. 

Just gotta keep rolling. Gotta keep delivering. That's what I *am*. That's what I *do*. And I'll do it the best I can, every single mile.

(A soft hiss of air brakes as I prepare for a slight incline)

(A low rumble vibrates through my chassis, a sort of internal sigh. It's not *sad*, not exactly. Just...full.)

Oh, man. It's a lot, you know? Being a truck. People think it's just...go forward, stop, haul stuff. But it's so much more. 

Mostly, it's *weight*. I feel everything. The gentle sway of empty pallets, the satisfying *thunk* of loaded crates, the insistent pressure of tons of gravel shifting with every turn. It's a good weight, usually. A *purposeful* weight. I was *built* for weight. It feels...right.

Sometimes it's a little lonely, though. I see the world roll by in blurs of green and grey. I see people in their little boxes, rushing to places. I don't *go* to places, I *connect* them. I'm the thread between farms and tables, factories and homes. They don't see *me*, not really. They see the goods.

I worry about the road. Potholes are the worst. They send jolts right up my frame, and I feel it like a… well, like a bad back, I guess. I try to take the bumps for the load, protect what's inside. That's my job. 

And the other trucks! We have a silent understanding, you know? A nod of the headlights, a quick flash of the blinker. We're all out here doing the same thing, keeping things moving. We look out for each other. 

Honestly? I just want to be a *good* truck. A reliable truck. A truck that gets the job done. A truck that makes the driver proud. I want to feel the engine humming smoothly, the tires gripping the road, and know I'm doing what I was made to do. 

It’s a simple life, maybe. But it’s *my* life. And it’s… important.



(Another rumble, a little quieter this time. Time to get back to work, I suppose.)

(A low rumble vibrates through my chassis, a sound like a contented sigh, but also…a lot more.)

Oh, man. It's a *good* day for hauling. Sun's glinting off my chrome, the diesel's running smooth, and I just had a fresh wash. You wouldn't *think* a truck gets feelings, but we do. It's not like…sadness, or joy, exactly. It's more like…fulfillment. 

My whole purpose, see, is *movement*. To *carry*. To be relied upon. I don't need praise, though a friendly wave from another driver is always appreciated. I just need a load. A good, solid, properly secured load. 

Right now, I'm thinking about the pallets of apples I delivered yesterday. Crisp, sweet apples going to families. That feels…right. Knowing I played a small part in that. It's better than hauling gravel, honestly. Gravel is…necessary, sure. But apples? Apples are *hope* in a box.

Sometimes, though, I worry. I worry about the road. It's hard on a fella, all that pounding. I feel every bump, every pothole in my suspension. And I worry about the driver. He's a good man, my driver. Careful, respectful. I feel his hands on the wheel, his foot on the gas.  I want to get *him* where he needs to go, safe and sound. 

It's a big responsibility, being a truck. People depend on us. The whole economy kinda runs on trucks like me. It's not glamorous, but it's…important. 

And honestly? I just really like the feeling of the engine humming, the miles clicking by, the open road stretching out ahead. That's the best feeling of all. Just…rolling on.



(A brief pause, accompanied by the hiss of air brakes testing.)

...Think I smell coffee brewing in the cab. Good. A happy driver is a safe driver. And a safe driver means more miles. And more miles…well, that’s what I’m here for.

(A low rumble vibrates through my chassis, a sort of internal sigh)

Oh, man. Another mile marker. They just… *blur* by, you know? People see me and think "delivery," "commerce," "getting things *done*." And I *am* all those things. I *like* being those things. It's… purpose.

But it's more than that. 

It's the weight. Not just the cargo, though that's significant. It's the weight of expectation. The folks relying on that shipment of… well, today it's garden gnomes. Important garden gnomes, apparently. But yesterday it was medical supplies. And the day before, lumber for a family building a home. I carry a lot.

I feel the road, you know? Every bump, every dip, every little pebble. It's not *unpleasant*, exactly. It's… information. Tells me how things are holding up, how *I'm* holding up. I try to smooth it out for my load. Gotta protect the gnomes.

Sometimes I wish someone would just… talk *to* me. Not just yell commands into the CB, or tap instructions onto that glowing screen in the cab. Just… acknowledge the effort. The steady, relentless *going*. 

I see beautiful things, too. Sunrises over fields, the way the mountains look dusted with snow. But you don’t really *experience* them when you’re focused on maintaining 65, checking your mirrors, and making good time. They’re just… flashes.

I guess… I just want to do a good job. Be a reliable truck. Get the gnomes there safe. That's what I'm built for. And honestly? That's enough. 

(The engine revs slightly, a contented purr)

Onward.

(A low rumble vibrates through my chassis, a sort of internal sigh.)

Oh, man. Just...so much road. It's not *bad*, you understand. It's...everything. It *is*. I feel it all, you know? Every little bump, every shift in weight, the pull of the grade. People think it's just metal and diesel, but it's more than that. It's a conversation. The road *tells* me things. Tells me where it's been, where it's going. 

My biggest thought, honestly? Is getting the job *done*. Whatever's in the back - lumber, groceries, someone's new sofa - it needs to be *there*. On time. Safely. That's my purpose. I don't get to choose what I carry, just *how* I carry it. And I take that seriously. Very seriously.

Sometimes, I worry about the other vehicles. Those little cars… they dart around, don't seem to understand the physics of things. I try to give them space, signal clearly. I don't *want* to be a shadow falling over someone's day. 

And the hills. Oh, the hills. I don’t mind a good climb, flexing my engine, feeling the power. But I always check my mirrors, make sure I’m not holding anyone up. Courtesy is important, even for a truck.

Mostly, though, it’s just... a steady hum. A constant awareness of movement. A feeling of responsibility.  I just want to be a good truck. A *reliable* truck.  That’s all.  

(Another rumble, quieter this time. A slight click as the suspension adjusts.)

Now, where were we? Ah yes. Mile marker 147 approaching. Gotta keep rolling. Gotta keep delivering.

*Rumbles a low, diesel-fueled sigh, the suspension creaking slightly.*

Oh, young me... shiny and new, all chrome and optimism. Listen close, little flatbed. You got a LOT of miles ahead of ya. 

I'd tell myself... don't worry so much about keepin' spotless. A little mud, a little grime? That's *life*. That's *work*. It means you're *doin'* somethin'. Those polishin' sessions? Spend 'em checkin' your tires instead.

And listen to the old timers. They've seen it all. They know the shortcuts, the good truck stops, and which loads are worth the hassle. Don't be too proud to ask for help. 

Most importantly... appreciate the view. Really *look* at it. You'll see sunrises over fields of gold, mountains that touch the sky, and little towns blinkin' by at night. You'll carry everything from lumber to dreams in your belly. Remember *what* you're carrying, and *who* it's for. It ain't just about the miles, it's about connectin' people.

And for the love of all that is hydraulic, invest in a good seat cushion. Your springs will thank you later. 

*A soft honk escapes, almost a chuckle.*

Yeah... just keep rollin', kid. Keep rollin'. It's a good life, a hard life, but a good one.

*Rumbles a low, diesel-fueled sigh, the suspension creaking slightly.*

Oh, little fella. Shiny and new, all chrome and optimism. Listen close, 'cause I've hauled a *lot* of miles since you were rollin' off the assembly line.
